awd_titl_txt: Collaborative: AIM & ICERM Research Experiences for Undergraduate Faculty Workshops
awd_abstract_narration:
Enabling more Americans to earn undergraduate and graduate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) is important to improving American innovation capabilities.  Participating in research as undergraduates improves retention in STEM majors and encourages students to pursue graduate degrees.   Faculty at colleges and universities that focus on undergraduate education are critical to this mission, yet in many cases such faculty receive little support to do research with the students they teach or continue their own research, and doctoral programs often fail to train their graduates to mentor undergraduate research.  To address this national need, the American Institute of Mathematics (AIM) and the Institute for Computational and Experimental Research in Mathematics (ICERM) will conduct a series of four annual Research Experiences for Undergraduate Faculty (REUF) workshops during the summers of 2016, 2017, 2018, and 2019.  Each REUF workshop and ongoing activities will provide a new group of faculty participants at undergraduate institutions that have limited research support with a research experience investigating open questions in the mathematical sciences and equip them to engage in research with undergraduate students at their home institutions. 

At each REUF workshop four senior mathematicians (leaders) who have experience doing research with undergraduate students will present problems in a variety of areas, after which the participants and leaders will divide into groups and work on the problems; the workshop will conclude with group presentations of each project. Most of the time will be spent doing research, but there will also be whole group discussions about topics such as best practices in undergraduate research led by the (co)-principal investigators, who also meet daily with the leaders. There are opportunities to continue work on the projects started in the workshop, and some participants will become involved in long-term research collaborations with other faculty at the workshop.  The recruitment efforts for REUF will target faculty at undergraduate colleges and universities that serve a large proportion of students who are underrepresented minorities, person with disabilities, or first generation college students, as well as faculty who are themselves underrepresented or have disabilities. The REUF project will lead to more and better undergraduate research experiences for the students of the faculty participants, and greater engagement in mathematical research by the faculty participants, thus expanding and diversifying the mathematical workforce.

por.por_cntn:
The American Institute of Mathematics (AIM), in partnership with the Institute for Computational and Experimental Research in Mathematics (ICERM), conducted annual Research Experiences for Undergraduate Faculty (REUF) workshops during the summers of 2016, 2017, 2018, and 2019, and additional activities for participants afterwards to support continuation of research engagement sparked by the workshop.

By supporting the involvement of undergraduate faculty in research in the mathematical sciences with undergraduates, the REUF workshops have an immediate impact on these faculty and their students. Many of the faculty participants spread the culture of undergraduate research throughout their departments, thereby having a long term on their colleges and universities and many future students.

At each REUF workshop four senior mathematicians (leaders) who have experience doing research with undergraduate students present problems in a variety of areas, after which the participants and leaders divide into groups and work on the problems; the workshop concludes with group presentations of each project. Most of the time is spent doing mathematics, but there are also whole group discussions about topics such as best practices in undergraduate research led by the organizers. Since numerical experiments and computational investigations are crucial to much of the research done with undergraduates, the workshops also include instruction in using the free open-source mathematics software Sage. AIM and ICERM directors facilitate the management of the workshop, and participants receive full funding. More information about REUF can be found on the REUF website, http://reuf.aimath.org/.

In many cases, the research projects begun at the workshop continue via virtual meetings. Often another week-long small group is needed to complete the results and prepare them for publications; this grant funded 14 such small group research meetings. An example of the long-term effect of REUF is that an undergraduate mentored by a REUF faculty member in 2014-2015 earned a PhD and joined a REUF small research group meeting held in summer 2021. Other notable outcomes: 

  • Special sessions at the Joint Mathematics Meetings organized by REUF alumni. 
  • Development of new undergraduate courses on REUF research topics. 
  • Departmental changes such as the creation of a for-credit undergraduate research seminar for math majors

Specific outcomes of the REUF workshops since 2008 that involve participating undergraduate faculty include:

  • 221 faculty from more than 100 primarily undergraduate institutions have participated in a REUF workshop.

  • 390 undergraduate students were mentored by REUF alumni in research.

  • 277 student research presentations.

  • 22 honors/senior theses supervised.

  • 9 publications with student (co-)authors (including 3 supported by this grant).

  • 52 faculty publications based on REUF research (including 19 supported by this grant)

  • 34 grants for faculty-student collaboration.


 


Last Modified: 03/24/2022
Modified by: Ulrica Wilson
